@tmWasted Not false. I said historical emitter. Only in recent years has China surpassed USA in yearly emission rate, and even then the per capita emissions for China are lower due to their substantially larger population. The atmosphere's thermal balance only cares about total amount of heat-trapping gases, total contribution. Furthermore, if one takes into account a good chunk of China's manufacturing sector emissions are based on exports for USA consumption, then China just recently surpassing USA is even less significant. Take into account manufacturing exports and the USA's yearly emissions would be substantially higher than China's. Furthermore, the Chinese have substantially more R&D money going into GHG sequestration and reduction than USA Energy Dept. They are taking steps in some ways already where the Paris Accord has their obligations delayed somewhat. The EU is in much the same situation relative to the USA, doing more despite having a smaller per-person contribution to the problem. Try as you might to escape responsibility, the facts show that on a per-person basis a USA citizen has had far more contribution to the problem than a Chinese citizen. The Paris Accord is fair, and in fact generous to the USA. That being said, the framers of the Paris Accord might have figured on anticipating a selfish backlash from high emission nations and planned on a same-time start date for all countries, but with differing percentage contributions. That being said, the world's negotiations can't drop everything just to please these people, either.

Daniel Martins and Piotr Czajkowski, no that is the defeatism that plays into the strategy regarding those that don't want to do anything about the issue. Layback Studios and TheCatLord, there was a lot of careful planning and negotiation into the Paris Accord. It was based on the assumption that it is fair for the major causes of the problem to take on a bit of the earlier share. The USA is by a good margin the largest historical emitter, both per capita and the country as a whole. The agreement was fair, and in fact even generous to the USA in some respects given our country's primary role in the existing greenhouse gases. One could argue that nobody knowingly wanted to change the atmosphere in this way, but consequences are consequences. No amount of selfish economic interest posturing will change that especially when our country is most easily poised to make the biggest difference early on. There are Saudi Arabia sized energy efficiency gains to be had in the USA, and that is just efficiency, not counting energy conservation, R&D, and lower GHG sources like nuclear, etc.

Causes of climate change

Transportation: cars, trucks, semis, airplanes, motorcycle, ATVs
Energy: internal combustion engine generators, natural gas, coal power plants
Meat farms: cows pigs chickens and all meat but cows are the worst
Construction: concrete, smelting
Industry in general

Solutions
Energy: SOLAR panels, wind energy, BATTERIES, pumped hydro storage, nuclear, hydrogen
Transport: electric cars trucks busses trains motorcycles and ATVs, hydrogen fuel cell planes and ships
Construction: innovations in construction material beyond concrete, smelting without using coal

Makeshift solutions/slower long term repair
Direct carbon capture and carbon capture devices activated when there is to much energy to prevent waisted energy

But most of the changes aren't policy (policy helps) but it's the people that will have to change to hit these goals.

Just to be clear, both Climate Change and Global Warming are separate things. They are normal events that happen throughout Earth's history. The main issue is the speed of Global Warming. The ecosystems of planet Earth are not accustomed for a quick change in temperature rather a gradual one (we are talking thousands of years). However, Earth has it's own mechanisms to reduce CO2 in the environment. This is increase in it's cooling like hurricanes and storms, ocean absorption but they can do so much until they are ineffective. Another is due to Orbital positioning and Solar Minimum (Solar maximum would basically cause hotter temperatures). Last time I checked we were still in a Solar Minimum. Spring is when most of Earth's CO2 dissipates from the air. Which helps a lot in diminishing CO2 concentrations. The main problem is gases like methane and other high carbon chain gases. Though they dissipate fast, they cause heavy damage. This is where we should tackle the problem first.

You do realize that skepticalscience.com is run by a political communication professor? In other words, not only does he know how to spin a lie as the truth, but he teaches it. The *falsehood* here is that they claim people are trying to say that ghg's effect does not exist. Yes, it does exist or we would not be alive. No one doubt that's. What has not been proven is the sensitivity of the atmosphere to co2 changes. Let me ATTEMPT to explain it. By itself, with nothing else, co2 can rise the temperature about 1°C to 2°c in AN ENCLOSED ENVIRONMENT. Add water vapor, or as they do in many cases, ice, and you can easily caused the ENCLOSED ENVIRONMENT to get 3° or even 5° warmer. BUT the atmosphere is not an enclosed environment. In order to get from the 1° to 8°c they have to add multiple POSITIVE feedbacks, and totally ignore the NEGATIVE feedbacks of the atmosphere. Lets look at one of them: clouds. If clouds form low, they are highly reflective of sunlight. This causes MORE sunlight to be reflected back into space. In addition, low level clouds are more TRANSPARENT to infrared. So the more of energy that earth radiates is lost to space. High level clouds are the reverse. They ABSORB more sunlight, warming the atmosphere. They are also more REFLECTIVE of infrared. That is why on a cloudy day, with high clouds, its warmer at night. They reflect the infrared the earth radiates back to the earth. The early computer models had ever cloud high level. Even today they will admit they do not know how to model the clouds. Another negative feedback the alarmist refuse to even consider is that co2 radiates energy into space. Every model they use shows the infrared leaving the planet being reduced as co2 goes up. Satellites from the 1990's prove the reverse. Increasing co2 means increasing infrared leaving the planet. This is a negative feedback NOT ONE of the models consider. "for your very first claim" The *falsehood* here is that I did not use greenhouse data. I used satellite data. As I said, the blogs you use are written by a professional spin doctor who knows how to spin falsehoods to sound like they are true.

Denying global warming requires that one must first deny the physical science of the greenhouse effect:
Electromagnetic radiation includes Infrared Radiation (IR) and visible light. Both are absorbed by the surface of the Earth and converted to kinetic energy (heat). This heat is emitted back outward as thermal radiation aka IR. A significant amount of this IR is reabsorbed by the denser atmospheric gases such as water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, etcetera (not nitrogen and oxygen). This excites their molecular structure and the resulting kinetic energy re-emits IR. Life on Earth is made possible by the capturing of enough IR to keep the biosphere warm enough to sustain life. As the heavier molecules in the atmosphere increase, the amount of IR also increases.

Science classes are classes where you perform experiments and make conclusions based upon your ability to repeat the findings of those experiments. Basic Earth Science classes are not science classes. They are propaganda classes where you are taught what to think. Bottom line? CO2 increases follow the heating of the Earth, not the other way around. Need proof, here's some from a guy who will back up your argument by telling you only part of the story in order to camouflage his lie by admitting and then twisting the truth. Here you go: https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov/11362 WARNING: What you'll read in the opening three paragraphs is truth mixed with nonsense, because while the Director of the Earth Science Division at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center does indeed admit that pre-industrial times show CO2 lagging the heating of the planet, he does not explain why the planet would have heated in the first place during these pre-industrial times when CO2 started out low and then climbed along with the temperature increase. Think about it... If he did tell you why the Earth got warmer during those times without a preceing increase in CO2, you might just ask yourself if that same factor might be heating the Earth now as well, and that certainly wouldn't have served his purpose now would it? The answer? Whether or not you buy into CO2 acting as a substantial greenhouse gas, we can all agree that when it comes down to it, it is the SUN that heats our planet. Unfortunately, what the scientists fail to tell the Global Warming/Climate Change believers is that when the sun throws off more solar winds, it blocks cosmic rays, which all scientists know are integral to the Earth's formation of clouds. Less clouds = more heat reaching the Earth = increased temperatures. Bottom line? Human production of CO2 is a tiny part of all CO2 released and is negligible when compared to CO2 released from volcanos and the natural degredation of plant particles. The bad news is that we can't turn down the sun or alter its processes. The good news is that during Medieval Times, the Medieval Warm Period brought 300 years of added wealth and prosperity that actually resulted in a doubling of the world's population, so even if the sun doe bump up the overal temperature by a few degrees, it's going to be a boon, not a bust for the people of the Earth.

CO2 is a greenhouse gas. That is it both absorbs and releases infrared photons. Once released, there is one chance in 41,253 that infrared photon will continue within one degree in the same direction. This basically gives that photon a 50/50 chance of going either up or down. Since the oceans cover about 71% of the Earth's surface, this gives that photon about a 35% chance of hitting a body of water. Infrared photons will not penetrate a body of water's surface, but will instead excite an H2O molecule causing evaporation. H2O is the primary greenhouse gas which prevents the Earth from having a climate like our moon. Consequently, the more CO2 we put into the atmosphere, the more H2O gets into the atmosphere, the warmer the planet gets. This is how a 40% increase in CO2 caused a 7% increase in absolute humidity. The present increase in temperature due to this combination of additional H2O and CO2 in the atmosphere is approximately .9C at present. Because it takes a tremendous amount of time for the oceans to heat, it will take centuries for the Earth to reach temperature equilibrium. If we continue to inject 35 gigatonnes annually of CO2 into the atmosphere, that heating process will continue to accelerate.

As the atmosphere warms, the differential temperature decreases between the ocean's surface and the atmosphere, blocking the ocean from releasing its heat. That is where 93% of the additional heat is being stored. This additional heat in the oceans will not only melt the ice caps but will allow vastly larger hurricanes to form and travel at much greater distances. The imminent threat isn't sea level rise but a future of massive storm surges. LOCKBOX...What an idiot. Solar activity fluctuates in an 11-year cycle. But so far in this cycle, the sun has been disturbingly quiet. The lack of increased activity could signal the beginning of what is known as a Maunder Minimum, an event which occurs every couple of centuries and can last as long as a century.
Such an event occurred in the 17th century. The observation of sunspots showed extraordinarily low levels of magnetism on the sun, with little or no 11-year cycle.
This solar hibernation corresponded with a period of bitter cold that began around 1650 and lasted, with intermittent spikes of warming, until 1715. Frigid winters and cold summers during that period led to massive crop failures, famine and death in Northern Europe.
Tapping reports no change in the sun's magnetic field so far this cycle and warns that if the sun remains quiet for another year or two, it may indicate a repeat of that period of drastic cooling of the Earth, bringing massive snowfall and severe weather to the Northern Hemisphere.

@Jon Hanson "The climate is a cycle" Sure, but let me tell you why current climate change is a real problem since it's evident you know nothing about the subject. The problem is not "that the climate is changing", the problem is the RATE at which we see the climate changing. Sure a past extinction event could have been caused, and likely was caused, by global warming that made the Earth much hotter than it is today. But that change ramped up over a period of hundreds of thousands of years, a very quick change on the geologic time scale. The change we are seeing now is orders of magnitude faster than anything in the past, which means it's likely to cause an avalanche effect with all the positive feedback for a warming Earth once it starts, which it has. It's a classic example of an under damped system with positive feedback, in other words if we stopped ALL C02 emissions TODAY, we would still have Earth continuing to warm for hundreds if not thousands of years based on the past 150 years of emissions alone. I'm sure you've seen the chart of the warmest decade on record being the past 10 years; that's the climate just now catching up to about the first couple decades of emissions at the beginning of the industrial revolution. That's why our emissions today are such a big problem.

Weather station/monitoring data is public. Climate is not just the moving temperature average but also seasonal temperatures, rainfall, temperature-volatility, irregular freezing in spring or autumn, greenhouse gases and ocean currents. Weather is the day-to-day temperature and rainfall instead of the long-term trends and volatility. I agree that it's warm in the summer and cold in the winter, but these peaks and lows aren't the same every year. Especially since we hit existentially-threatening 400ppm CO2 levels that threaten the runaway feedback loop of increasing temperatures and relative humidity, water vapor, and desertification. Even with the ice sheets melting and the oceans absorbing the majority of CO2, we are still seeing cataclysmic disaster on a global scale, while it's still reversible through drastic emergency cuts to emissions and reforestation & carbon sequestration initiatives.

Allow me to throw a little bit of facts on your fire. 1) For the majority of earth's history, the temperature was 26°c. Most of the time it wasn't, it was 11°c The rest of the time it floated between 28° and 11°. Currently we are 14.5°. That's 3°C above the coldest the planet has ever been. 2) We are in an ice age, created by Antarctica and the Himalayan mountains freezing over. Unless you move those two, the temperature can not climb more than 3°C hotter than it is now. That is because of the earths albedo. There is so much ice and snow on the planet that it is reflecting a large portion of the suns energy back into space. 3) when both of those areas froze, the co2 levels were at 1500 ppm. How can the co2 increasing from 350 to 410 cause them to melt? EVEN if as the scientist predict, the co2 goes to 750 by 2100, it will not be more than half of what the atmosphere  held when those froze. The most that increasing co2 that much would do is raise it by 3°c because that is the limit that the albedo creates. That is not sufficient to melt the ice in the world.

The NASA blog said it was disappearing, but the graph did not show what he said it did. The graph showed increases of 1-3 inches per year as light green, increases of more as dark green, and decreases in red similarly. There was a good bit more dark red than dark green, which is where they got their claim, BUT the dark red showing 3-10 inches of decrease were tiny compared to the area increase. Perhaps 2% of the map showed a decrease, while 90% showed an increase (about 5-7% showed no change) Even if the entirety of the decreasing area was the full 10 inches (not likely) and even if the 90% only had 1 inch (not likely), you still had more than snow falling each year than disappearing. SB 652 defines 21 categories of private facilities, including pipeline and gas processing plants, as “critical infrastructure facilities.” The bill would make it a felony of the first or second degree if any person enters onto the property of such a facility with the intent of “impeding or inhibiting” operations.  Under current law, it’s considered a summary or misdemeanor offense. To all who has disliked this video and all who will dislike this video, I totally understand if Vox is not your number one news site that you trust. Of course we all have our preferences for the news and incidents where news outlets purposely skew some news events for their own agenda have made people skeptical.


However, if you disliked this video not for which site displays this content but for the content itself, then think about this.

There has been a trend in global disasters occurring. All over the world, temperatures are getting hotter, sea levels are getting higher, rain has been getting heavier. More and more natural disasters have been devastating our earth, and even those against climate change can't deny we are seeing these natural disasters not only more frequently, but more quickly too.

If you don't trust numbers generated and/or agreed upon by 98% of the world's scientists, trust the anguished cries of those trapped by natural disasters.

Trust the grief of those who have lost someone in a natural disasters, regardless of where it has happened. Trust the billions of dollars lost because we don't take a stand against emitting carbon dioxide gases that are warming our planet and making that one child in California lose all he or she knows on a devastating forest fire. Trust the exhaustion of so many rescue workers who have to see the same scene over and over again because we are too busy trying to denounce each other's political ideologies and bickering amongst ourselves to even CARE.

People all around the world are TIRED of having to deal with their family members dying everyday. So why aren't we doing anything??

It won't take much for us to do anything, and it definitely shouldn't be just governments doing anything. But if governments, the institutions we rely on to govern our lives, refuse to do anything significant to help anyone, to stop what's been happening in Laos or Indonesia or Thailand or California from happening to anyone else, then when will we?

Climate change is not a theory, or a scientific hypothesis waiting for someone to prove it and be awarded a Nobel Prize for. It is something that is happening every single second we live on this earth.

Here is how we stop climate change.
1. Invest in GMO research to allow for higher yield, low maintenance crops. A lot of GHG's actually come from agriculture. GMO crops could require less water, and GMO feeds could be better for livestock, which also produce GHG's.
2. Gradually replace coal-fired plants with nuclear and natural gas. The renewables like wind and solar are nice, but are auxiliary sources, not primary sources of energy. Actually, we could become the world's exporter of nuclear reactors and fuel, which could be a huge boon to the economy.
3. Massively increase the extraction of natural gas, this should come to replace oil as our primary energy export. Natural gas is WAY cleaner than oil and coal.
4. Plant more trees. In fact, encourage more forestry operations in the otherwise unused land. We have the tech to reclaim desert and arid land and make it arable, we should use the land for tree farms and other forms of forestry. Such technology has been proven in Spain, lets use it in the US.

Unfortunately, most environmentalists are against natural gas, nuclear energy and GMO crops. Ironic, given that they could significantly reduce emissions.

+Duck Hunt Trash Wind and solar are generally supplementary power sources. The problem with solar and wind is that they pretty much are forced to run at 100% capacity due to how they operate (a windwills power output is dictated by the wind, not the operator, same with solar panels). This causes problems with scalability. If your wind farm has 10 mills, generates 50mW, and the power consumption increases to 52mW, you now have to construct a new mill. So now our farm has 11 mills, and 55mW of output, but only 52mW of consumption, so 3mW are being wasted. In the case of a traditional fission power plant (or any other power plant for that matter), the output can be adjusted by the operators. If my power plant has a maximum output of 100mW (at 100%), but the requirement is only 50mW, then the operators can limit output to 50% (50mW), no power is wasted in this case. If the requirement increases to 60mW, then the output limit can be adjusted to 60% (60mW). Again, no energy is lost, as energy output is controlled by the operator, not by natural forces. Because standard plants maximum capacity is typically significantly higher than the demand, they are able to easily react to increases in demand, without energy loss. Since output can be changed on the fly, as opposed to installing new panels or mills, the costs of increasing output are also much lower than standard renewables. Furthermore, since operations are centralized, maintenance is easier. This is the advantage of traditional power over renewables. Renewables are still useful. They provide very cheap power, and for areas with low power demands, such as suburban or rural areas, they are superior to standard plants. For large metropolitan areas or areas with heavy industry, power requirements are immense and fluctuate, so standard power plants are preferable in those cases. Now, let's not forget about Hydroelectric! Hydro actually has all the benefits of traditional plants without the drawbacks of other renewables. The only tradeoff is that construction and operation costs are staggering compared to other sources of energy. Now as for nuclear energy being non-renewable, I actually disagree. It's technically non-renewable, but it's about the most renewable non-renewable source of energy. Nuclear fuel can be reused and recycled quite a number of times before becoming totally useless. Disposal of spent fuel is non-trivial. Literally, just dig in a salt-rich mountain (ie somewhere out in the middle of Nevada), throw the fuel into the hole and forget about it. The salt provides radiation shielding, and desolate and arid climate will prevent potential leakages due to erosion. For the US, due to our massive power consumption, I propose that about 40% of generation be Nuclear, 30% be Hydroelectric, and the rest be Solar, Wind, and Geothermal. With this model, our energy sector would emit no carbon, and still provide huge amounts of energy. Some smaller nations, like in Europe, could get away with almost 90% being purely hydroelectric. Those nations have some very large rivers and generally, have smaller populations with lower power requirements.

Environmentalist here. Natural Gas is what a lot of environmentalists call a middle ground of some sorts. It's much cleaner and better chan coal or oil, but it still has a lot of environmental concerns. Natural Gas still causes emissions even if it is a lesser amount. Fracking is also believed to do a lot of local damage, notably to water supplies and leads to more earthquakes. Nucleur, Solar, Wind, etc. are much more environmental friendly. Most environmentalists dont have as big of an issue with nuclear energy. It's much more safe than what we do now, but thorium is not a renewable energy resource, while solar and wind energy are. Thats why many of us prefer to 'skip' nuclear and jump to renewable energy. And certain GMOs are not environmentally friendly. Specifically ones that have pesticides implemented, those seriously damage the local wildlife. GMO crops are something important and we should use them, but we should be environmentally aware of the issues with it.

This video gives me such a feeling of hopelessness for the future. Once upon a time, the biggest dividing factor on climate change was money. Companies that create CO2 emissions and other greenhouse gases as part of their manufacturing processes would pump tons of money into electoral campaigns to ensure that climate change deniers would find themselves in the seats of power. Now? Now it's not just about money. It's about "us vs them". Democrats vs Republicans. It's no longer a financial or scientific debate, but an ideological one. If there is one thing that history has shown it is that opposing ideological views rarely ever come to agreement, and even when they do it is after many, many years of struggle. Years that we don't have to waste.

Well, if it makes you feel any better, the money is still driving this ideological divide. When the money dries up for these think tanks and politicians to take on these crazy positions, they will probably naturally revert back to their former positions and we will magically start to see them dust off those old solutions they stood behind briefly in the mid-2000's decade.

Everything depends on how quickly we end the burning fossil fuels. Realistic projections have the global temperature increase at around 3.2°C by year 2100. There is only a 5% chance that warming will be less than 2°C. Increases in CO2 concentration in the atmosphere are largely irreversible for 1,000 years after emissions stop. Even if carbon emissions stop completely today, as the oceans heating catches up to greenhouse gases already in the atmosphere, the Earth's temperature will rise another ~0.6°C. Scientists refer to this as committed warming.

The best way to remove CO2 from the air," says Howard Herzog in his book Carbon Capture, is "to not release it into the air in the first place."

Miguel Hernandez Yup, it was present as organic (carbon) substances in this earth. It’s how the carbon cycle works— these organic substances contain high energy covalent bonds that produce energy that basically powers our society. Yes, the carbon was there before, but it wasn’t as CO2. What we need to do is to fix that CO2 back into organic carbon substances (which is done in photosynthesis), and at least slow down what we’re doing now. The problem is we’re not doing either.

@carl1223: The problem isn't solved by simply naming the obstacles in the way of solving it. One takes that first step of acknowledging these obstacles, but figures that there can be some means to compromise between conservation, efficiency, and alternatives in order to make progress and eventually meet the end goal. The next step is figuring out what could work and going for it. Will there be some R&D and breakthroughs needed? Yes. Will some sacrifices possibly have to be made? Sure. The point is, we don't know what is impossible until we try, and our 30-some years of procrastination and tepid attempts to try haven't produced all that much progress. The goal, some measure of human population living on this planet without excessively altering its condition in a way that threatens that human population. Ideas how that can happen, or you aren't contributing anything helpful.

Eliminate animal agriculture and you’re looking at the biggest single contributor to global warming being removed entirely. And thats as easy as switching whats on your plate. And no, it wouldn’t be costly.

The concept of money needs to go away before we're ever going to genuinely get to work on solving our most pressing issues. In absence of that sadly highly unlikely occurrence, the Global North needs to be de-growing in order to allow the Global South to grow to a sustainable level. Eventually, the goal should be that we're all on the same level and living within our one planet's means. (And no, that doesn't have to mean abandoning all the progress of the past 200 years.)

No, it isn't a matter of waiting until someone else fixes the problem. On the contrary, there is quite a lot of room for engaged citizens to make efforts to lobby for policy or organized solutions. Also, tragedy of the commons problems don't exclude individual actions. There is no reason why many individuals can't make certain lifestyle changes along with the system-level changes. So it is a matter of focus... focusing one's individual efforts towards pushing for systematic change.

As an individual you have very little effect on climate change because 71% of ghg emissions since 1988 have been produced by 100 companies. Lobbyists and marketers would like you to believe that you have personal responsibility for this crisis so that governments don’t hold companies accountable.

@warlord13000 The problem with the thinking that we as individuals can figure out how to do this on our own, is that no tragedy of the commons type problem has ever been solved that way. There are some reasons borrowed from game theory, but individuals don't naturally just band together to fix a public common problem like this. There is no organization and everybody ends up just doing a negligible amount or the bare minimum (often nothing) due to refusals to make larger sacrifices than any given neighbor or other citizen. It ends up as a race to the bottom, doing nothing or next to nothing as we have seen on AGW the past 30 some years. It is wishful thinking that we all just suddenly become aware and change this do-nothing trend massively. Like it or loathe it, but other problems like this had to be solved by some form of enforcement, whether it was the saving of the last bits of the Great Plains buffalo herds or the Montreal Protocol to get a handle on the ozone layer problem. We didn't win WWII by just figuring everybody would make a weapon or two and send them over to our boys to retake conquered lands from the Axis. Why would this problem that requires substantial economic mobilization be any different?

@Kevin Lai In answer to the first part of that question, the amount of CO2 (or CO2 equivalent) emissions of different energy sources is generally measured in CO2 per kilowatt hour, with most estimates taking full life cycle costs into account. I can't be bothered to track down a thoroughly reliable source for those stats (although I have in the past). but to give an indication of relative scale is the median estimates produced by a 2014 IPCC report; Coal - 820 Gas - 490 Solar PV (utility) - 48 Solar PV (rooftop) - 41 Offshore wind - 12 Nuclear - 12 Now, I can't defend those precise figures (the emissions involved in Solar energy relative to other forms, in particular, is probably complicated and down to the manufacturing process), but they do chime with what I've seen in other sources. According to official US EIA, nuclear makes up 20% of electricity generation in the US. I'm not going to sit down and do the maths, and how bad the effect would be depends on whether you are switching to coal or natural gas, but the increase in emissions clearly wouldn't be trivial. Would it single-handedly be responsible for global climate change? No, but it might be enough that we see, say, a fraction of a degree more warming by the end of the century than if that had not happened. That means a little bit more sea level rise, a little bit worse drought in the Sahel, a little bit worse flooding in South Asia, a little increase in global food prices (leading to a little increase in the risk of civil unrest in some countries)...etc.. Putting a firm number of lives on that is impossible, or at least, not something I'm willing to do, but on a global scale over a long period of time, I'd expect numbers in at least the six or seven figures. Now you say 'catastrophic incident'...what catastrophic incident? Calculating risk is about measuring the severity of a hazard against its likelihood. A hazard which is very severe, but is very unlikely does not constitute a risk - hence why governments aren't constantly in a panic over asteroids or nearby supernova. If nulcear waste is buried deep underground, in spots far apart geographically, nothing short of a planetary collision would cause all of it to leak. And at that point, radiation would be the least of our problems. It's not in anyway comparable to climate change - we *know* would happen, if emissions increase, and it is obviously realistic that they could. Seriously though, if you can name me one hazard, other than human tampering, that could cause stored nuclear waste all over the US to leak at once without also wiping out human civilisation, I would be eager to hear it.

@Merry Machiavelli ok so i just reread my comment and I saw how it could be misunderstood as "i think nuclear contamination is a greater threat than climate change". consider this thought experiment. Suppose you decommision every nuclear powerplant in the U.S. and replaced with fossil fuels. Yes, it will accelerate climate change. But by how much? More to the point, how much earlier will we reach tipping point threshold and what would be the difference in human fatalities? Now lets consider the reverse scenario. Lets say some catastrophic incident results in all the nuclear waste in all nuclear plants to be leaked into the environment. how many lives will be lost directly or indirectly? is this number greater or less than the former scenario? I have no idea. but if the latter is higher, then i must conclude the threat of nuclear contamination is greater than the threat of a accelerated global warming due to replacing nuclear plants with fossil fuel plants.

@Kevin Lai The risk of nuclear waste contamination is not, under any realistic scenario, comparable to the risk from climate change. Firstly, as crude as it sounds, digging a very deep hole and burying the waste is actually a pretty effective safety measure - sites are carefully selected based on their geology so that, even if humans were to disappear tomorrow, no additional radiation would be felt at the surface - in some places they even design them with the return of ice sheets in thousands of years in mind. Secondly, nuclear waste and climate change are on completely incomparable scales as hazards - nuclear accidents/waste residues are localised, the effects are predictable and quantifiable, and dimish to levels that aren't _that_ harmful, to humans or especially the environment, pretty quickly. At worst, people can just move away from the affected area. Climate change screws over humanity and the environment in so many ways, it's hard to know where to start. Nuclear power stations aren't the only way of generating electricity, but until we can find a way of _storing_ electricity or efficiently transmitting it long distances, intermittent renewables present issues if you want to move to 100% fossil-fuel free electricity. As it stands, when the sun isn't shining and the wind doesn't blow, you _need_ fossil fuel or nuclear plants to keep the lights on - this isn't a problem when renewables make up a minority of the energy mix, but we need to do better than that.

Wallowing in despair helps nothing; the tone of this video is just discouraging, and at a time when further discouragement is not necessary.

And it's only part of the story. Yes, in the United States many politicians have dragged their heels every inch of the way, but the past 20 years has still seen dramatic improvements in terms of emissions per kilowatt hour, and a huge improvement in fuel economy for our vehicles. We have been doing better, and while we have distance to go, there is hope.

The potential for proven technology; wind, solar, smarter grid systems, electric vehicles; has only begun to be tapped. This isn't hypothetical anymore, this is stuff that is competing on the market and winning.

Coal is already a dying industry, and in 10 or 15 years, oil is likely to follow.

So if you care about climate change, turn this video off, and go find out what you can do in your own life to make a change. Get out there and vote, support organizations that promote environmentally sustainable technology, volunteer your time. Whatever you can do. Together we will continue the transition to a sustainable economy.

There are two ways to be suspicious about the current climate <del>pun intended</del> about climate change: if you believe that the earth is getting warmer, as it seems to be the case, that doesn't mean the world 'is coming to and end'. We, as human beings, should adapt just as we shouldn't build houses near the coast so the next hurricane just don't blow the whole thing up. It's always weird when we talk about 'natural disasters' we don't ask ourselves how 'natural' they are. And that was only an example because we know that there's no scientific evidence, according to the IPCC, for a correlation between climate change and hurricanes and storms. It is hard to pick one defining moment, but you can look up a memo by Frank Luntz from a strategy meeting with Republican party officials. In it, there is an infamous line about how to use certain words that don't sound as scary to the public "use climate change instead of global warming" and the whole summary is couched in the political party's goals and not much concerned about whether the scientific problem is significant. Other than that, there have been certain fossil fuel industry public relation efforts that have been evolving since the late 1980's that have tried to make some political statements about the science.

I do agree with the video that this is a government issue but there is also so much that WE can do as citizens of this country to make the changes necessary. We know we cannot count and rely on our government so we need to find ways to take matters into our own hands and work together. Yes, one thing we can do is go out and vote that does help. But what a lot of people also don’t realize is that one of the easiest ways to help combat climate change is our consumption and I’m not just talking about oil and fossil fuels I’m also talking about the actual food we eat.

It is known that the animal agriculture industry is one of of the top contributors to greenhouse gases in our atmosphere so we, as a collective can make a conscious effort to consume less. The less consumption, the less demand there will be and therefore less supply will be needed.

I’m not saying you need to be 100% vegan or vegetarian but at least taking one or two days out of your week to not consume animal products can make a huge difference! I know people hate vegans and they always think they’re all righteous and what not but please do your own research and see how much of a difference we can all make if we just made minor lifestyle adjustments.

Same thing goes for waste, be conscious of your plastic use and try to use reusable items when possible.

I agree with the content of this video, Vox, but I don't like the music track behind it. It distracts from the main content, which is people talking - at various levels of audibility. Adding music for me to filter out makes it needlessly difficult to hear the actual content. Second, the music was chosen to 'set the mood' - which is unnecessary in this situation. It smacks of programming the viewer or pandering, and is in my opinion a cheap trick. Let the message - via everyone's quotes - speak for itself. This probably seems like a minor issue I'm quibbling about to most people, but I think it's symbolic of a general trend (especially in Youtube) videos of over-production at the detriment of conveying meaning. For such a professional outfit like Vox to do this surprises me.

No. Carbon dioxide lags temperature; it does not cause it to increase and warm the planet. In other words, the hotter Earth becomes, the more CO2 is released from various natural sources. [It's well known that in a warm El Nino year, more CO2 is released by the ocean into the atmosphere (and less taken up by the ocean from the atmosphere), while during cool La Nina years just the opposite happens.] Read that again, the hotter Earth becomes, the more CO2 is released from various natural sources. In other words, the entire premise of anthropogenic or "man made" global warming (AGW) where increased atmospheric CO2 causes the temperature to rise is flawed from the beginning. To reiterate, global temperatures have been rising for the last 300 years since the Little Ice Age (LIA) and even climate alarmists cannot blame human activity as the cause. Now the scary part; there has been no increase in the earth's average temperature for over 18 years despite the increase in CO2 in the atmosphere. This recovery from the LIA is completely beneficial. Earlier springs and later falls means longer growing seasons and longer growing seasons means more food. Then there is that well-recognized 800-year global heating and cooling cycle and the undeniable effects of solar fluctuations and cosmic activity that just may have some small effect on our world's temperature. Just in case anyone is wondering what specifically is causing climate change, I will try to explain it now.

Greenhouse gases trap heat from the sun in the Earth’s atmosphere, not allowing it to escape to space. Due to industrialisation, the amount of greenhouse gases released into the atmosphere has increased dramatically over the last 150 years. Carbon Dioxide, the most common greenhouse gas, is produced by burning fossil fuels. A fossil fuel is a natural fuel like coal or gas which is created from dead organisms buried under the ground for millions of years. These fuels are not created fast enough to keep up with our current demand and we will run out of them some day. Fossil fuels are used to generate electricity and power transportation such as cars, airplanes and boats. In 2007, fossil fuels made up 86.4% of the world’s energy consumption. Due to this, a large amount of carbon dioxide is released into the environment from the production of energy. Plants are naturally supposed to convert Carbon Dioxide back into oxygen. Unfortunately, due to deforestation there are less plants to do this. Climate change will cause sea levels to rise, causing massive flooding all over the world, cause the average temperature to increase and will inevitably make it harder for life to exist on Earth.

There's a few big factors. The internet age has decentralized sources of information and put disinformation and propaganda on the same footing as evidence-based research and study. President Obama's efforts to fight climate change were opposed by the GOP as part of a broader effort to undermine his presidency and protect their political power. And perhaps most of all, there is a growing sense of despair as we come to realize that measures to stop global climate change are increasingly harmful to our way of life. 30 years ago, it may have been possible to stop climate change with a cap and trade bill and investments in renewable energy. Now, however, extreme financial burdens would really be required at this point to ensure that we stop climate change. Unfortunately, this isn't going to change without a true sea change within the GOP, and among the nation at large. Realistically, $10/gallon for gas, flights for $1k or more for cross-country flights, and exorbitant coal/natural gas electric power would be necessary, and right now, Americans (among others) aren't going to give up their comforts to save the planet.

Why not show charts of co2 emissions over that period? This video implies that talking about climate change means that action is not being taken.

PREVENTING CLIMATE CHANGE
(Small things you can do to make a difference)

Take public transit.
Ride a bike.
Car-share.
Switch to an electric or hybrid vehicle.
Dont use straws
Fly less (if you do fly, make sure you offset your emissions).

Change to energy-efficient light bulbs.

Unplug computers, TVs and other electronics when you’re not using them.

Wash clothes in cold or warm (not hot) water.

Dryers are energy hogs, so hang dry when you can and use dryer balls when you can’t.

Install a programmable thermostat.

Look for the Energy Star label when buying new appliances.

Winterize your home to prevent heat from escaping.

Get a home or workplace energy audit to identify where you can make the most energy-saving gains.

Consume less, waste less, enjoy life more

There has been no cross-sectional repeatable study directly attributing the primary cause of climate change to human activity.

Instead, we have many studies that together conclude that very notion. Many of them rule out individual possible causes, until any reasonable person figures that the large increase in heat trapping gases with isotope signatures from fossil fuels would be the cause. If you aren't listening to every national academy of science in the developed world reporting on the output of the scientific method, you aren't listening to science.

If our nation is a threat to the rest of the world, then when can we as ordinary US citizens expect other nations to take emergency defensive measures against the USA? By ignoring climate change, we are threatening other nations and their citizens, and they'll be forced to retaliate (hopefully before its too late, not that I want anybody to die obviously).

1. Vote, and choose politicians who don't pretend that it's all a Chinese hoax. This is by far the most important point - the rich and powerful control the world, at least try to make it so the powerful are not deniers with that little power of choice that is afforded to you - don't let China get away with saying that authoritarianism beats democracy on climate change 2. Reduce your meat consumption and/or prefer chicken to other meats - 1Kg of chicken takes just 20% of the resources compared to 1Kg of beef 3. When possible try to prefer green alternatives in everything you buy, but for god's sake RESEARCH what is actually 'green' before marching down the roads with "no nuclear" signs (nuclear is actually great for climate change since a few tonnes underground are better than billions of tonnes in our air and lungs) 3.1. Point 3 withstanding, remember that it's almost always better to KEEP a functioning non-green product over buying a new shiny green one if you don't actually need the replacement. Green things are great but producing them also harms the environment. EG don't throw away your 2-year-old gasoline car to buy a Tesla 4. Transport modes from best to worst: - Bycicle/foot - Subway/Train in states and countries that use at least some nuclear and/or renewables - Bus/Other public transport + Subway/Train in states and countries that run only fossil - Electric, hydrogen, methane, LPG, diesel*, gasoline car in this order - Airplane (yes this is WORSE than gasoline and diesel) * On diesel: diesel is far WORSE than anything when it comes to _pollution_ , that is, poisonous particles that directly harm your body. However, from a thermodynamic standpoint it is more efficient than gasoline, which means it emits less CO2. Contrary to popular belief, CO2 and particulate are two separate things - particulate harms us and animals immediately like a poison, CO2 worsens global warming and harms the planet in the long run. With diesel you are trading our immediate physical health for a slight CO2 reduction compared to gasoline - I'd suggest not having to make that trade in the first place. Note: because particulate is really bad in cities, don't get diesel if you drive in cities as critical levels will cause it to be banned more and more in there.

@Generation Fallout It's no longer a question of "giving up"... it's a question of acknowledging reality. It's not "giving up" to acknowledge that your house has burned down because of your foolish habit of smoking in bed... your house has burned down, and now that's an indelible fact, as is your complicity in it's having gotten to such a state. The time to hope for a better outcome passed when you failed to put out your cigarette before nodding-off. Likewise, in the case of climate change, the forces involved have already reached a tipping point. We should have taken collective action decades ago, but we chose not to. Now we're paying the price, and our children will pay a greater price, and our grandchildren, a greater price still. While that fact should not stop us from continuing to do all we can to ensure the survival of our species, the truth is that fighting for survival is all we've got left, and it's far from an achievable goal now. Mert... I don't doubt the potential of fusion power or the potential for leaving fossil fuels in the near future - provided the political obstacle can get over it. And I admit. I'm a marine conservation scientist so I have my field of expertise and there are many others I would have to investigate before I could call myself a full climate expert (especially since I look into the biology side more than the physiochemical side) but that doesn't limit what I've read and seen. I'd like you to link me to these confused papers you describe so I can see if it's just interpretation or if it's the sourcing that's a little off... I know when I started reading around one subject I was googling the definitions of every other word just to keep up with the paper but as you get used to the language used, it gets easier to read them... And coffee helps immensely... The problem with climate change is not that 'it's happening' but that its happening way too fast. Imagine this: The last little ice age around 10,000 years ago was a cold point and after that, the world started warming. Then we hit the medieval warm period and it began to cool again until the got industrial and global temperatures began to pull up and as the human race industrialised, our carbon output magnified exponentially. You can understand that there is a limited amount of carbon on earth and that before we started burning coal, it was largely contained underground in oil and coal deposits. When we began to dig those up and burn it, we started bringing that carbon out of the ground stores and into the atmosphere. From there it has to deposit somewhere so it can dissolve into the oceans through a process called 'atmospheric deposition' and yes, for a while it will result in an increase in plant growth - but I'll get back to that later - it's not as simple as they want you to believe (every time I hear that argument my inner ecologist just screams). This carbon source and sink theory is pretty well founded and yes, it does reflect reality. It can be simplified to the simple idea of 'concentration gradients' - if anything is highly concentrated and there is nothing causing it to hold together (temperature is uniform/no static charges etc) then the concentration will diffuse 'down the gradient' and alike molecules will separate (it's the same concept that means oxygen will diffuse into your blood and carbon dioxide with diffuse out of your blood in the lungs but the gases don't stop each other from diffusing in opposite directions) so the oceans act as a giant global sink for just about anything in the atmosphere - ocean acidification is a simple chemical process that occurs when carbon dioxide is diffused into water - a polar molecule (as in it has little micro-electric charges on the molecule due to a concept known as 'electronegativity - this means that it only allows things to dissolve in it if it's molecules can be made equally polar - so salt dissolves into it's ions of sodium and chloride and in this case - Carbon Dioxide dissolves into carbonic acid. That's the chemistry bit done so if you're all good with that - let's move on to why this screws marine life. Limestone is Calcium Carbonate - it is made of the fossilised remains of calcium based lifeforms - largely a kind of phytoplankton called 'coccolithophores' but impurities remain in the form of anything also fossilised that isn't explicitly calcium carbonate based (- a fish skeleton isn't a carbonate and sharks don't have traditional bones) and this (in case you haven't seen the White Cliffs od Dover in the UK) makes up quite a huge amount of marine organisms - crustaceans (all crabs, lobsters and shrimps) have an exoskeleton made of this stuff (and shrimps or krill make up a hugely important component of fish diets (it's the reason salmon is pink, ask if you're unsure) which would have a drastic knock-on effects on fish stocks globally. Not to mention all shellfish in general would suffer and struggle to maintain populations - marine snails, clams, starfish, sea urchins and sea cucumbers (lovingly nicknamed the 'trashmen of the sea' for their role in material recycling. I include Echinoderms like starfish because they too have calcareous skeletons). Hope that's not too much, it's just about 6 textbooks worth of reading condensed into a rather specific topic. (Don't even get me started on corals - it would be another paragraph just like this one). Let's get to the feedback argument. The stability argument you make (or as I interpret it, clearly communicated ideas and answers are hard to come by but that's what's so great about the internet - near instant communication! We'll figure it out, don't you worry) comes from the point that the earth is a continually feedback influenced system. If albedo was to increase due to less sea ice - the water would be absorbing more of the sunlight than would have been reflected by the ice. Agreed? (Sorry, I need to know at which point this stops making sense to you, okay?) The water absorbs more sunlight and thus warms up more than with the sea ice overhead causing the water to expand (that's right, water expands with increasing temperature, water at around 4 degrees C is the densest water and it's why deep sea water is usually that temperature it sinks below colder and hotter water - not certain about the exact hydrodynamics though, I'm not an oceanographer). The expanded water takes up more land under it's area and the global ocean area is now a little bigger - allowing for more heat input from sunlight and causing further expansion. As the temperature increases at the surface, more evaporation takes place too, resulting in more sudden and violent storms (again, not a meteorologist but by understanding says this heating up is in no way good for land or for sea). Now, the actual problem with all of this climate change debacle is the pace it happens at. If the oceans only got slightly more acidic a little bit over a few thousand years, the species' as a whole that live there would have evential adaptations to let them survive and live into the next epoch. Same goes for terrestrial changes - if the oceans where to rise slowly over a few thousand years, then salt marsh species would be able to retreat with the land and nothing would really go extinct until an ecological collapse occurs (when enough species vital to the existence of an ecosystem - like trees in a forest or corals for a reef - where to stop living and stop existing. Essentially ending that environment and leaving the organisms that depend on that environment with adaptations that do them no favours at all - resulting in a chain of extinctions). What humans do however, is find news ways to force things to happen faster and more efficiently so of course we found almost all of the world's carbon deposits and released almost all of it into the atmosphere in just a few centuries (no normal volcano or even chain of volcanoes could do what we have already done). Humans have one thing I appreciate greatly - we can do things like no other species ever could. No beaver can make a dam like humans can, no bird can fly as high, no worm can dig as deep, no fish can swim as far and through technology we have almost broken this world. The least we could do is give at least some other organisms time to evolve and catch up with the new epoch we have created. By now, I hope I have outlined some of the mechanisms, of course having my oceanographer friend alongside me would help but she's on the other side of the planet right now currently investigating the effects of ocean acidification of coccolithophores. I realise that you will still have many many questions about the specifics of why this is such a bad thing and I can do my best to interpret exactly what it is you don't quite click with and why but that's why we need to end the shouting war and start communicating clearly and honestly. If there is anything I've described that doesn't quite make sense to you, reply with a clear and concise question on what it is you don't quite click with and I'll do my best to help.

@Mert Garbonite oh yeah, if you think you've considered everything the scientists haven't. Think again, read an actual paper on the subject by a major journal and you'll be sorely disappointed in your politicians. CO2 is a natural gas, but the system usually consists of both carbon sinks and carbon sources. There are natural sources like volcanos and natural forest fires and there are sinks like growing forests and the oceans are both depending on the relative saturation between the atmosphere and the water. But even if humans only add a small amount, it's a small amount that has nowhere to go in this already balanced system. Things where in equilibrium for a bit but now it's got a much heavier input. Now the oceans and atmosphere are receiving most of our input and the effect of CO2 in atmosphere leading to a greenhouse effect have been recorded and known for over 120 years. It's basically fact. What's more concerning for me (as a marine conservation scientist) is that it also saturates the oceans and as the carbon dioxide is dissolved into the water, it disaccoiates into carbonic acid. In case you hadn't noticed, the majority of marine life uses calcium based shells and skeletons. In an acid medium, these will all be dissolved which isn't just cruel and painful, it means the end of all marine snails, crustaceans and corals as well as many more delicate organisms (ever seen a nudibranch? One of the most amazing slugs you'll ever see, but they could quite easily be wiped out by this). Just remember, it's not that climate change is happening. It's that humans are making it happen way too fast. Species can evolve and survive, but at this rate we'll be lucky to have anything alive in 100 years.

Climate change is the perfect challenge that faces humans. Our brains fail to process climate change because it is exceptionally amorphous. It provides us with no defining qualities that would give it a clear identity: no deadlines, no geographic location, no single cause or solution and, critically, no obvious enemy. Our brains scan it for the usual cues that we use to process and evaluate information about the world, but find none. It defies the human psyche to take action to this threat and ultimately will lead to our downfall.

You misrepresent Republicans who doubt climate change as ignorant and self-centered, then refuse to actually define the difference between climate change and ANTHROPOGENIC climate change. But I suppose manipulating facts to fit a certain narrative is what Vox does best.

@dw5050 There are a couple discrepancies in that NatGeo video. Firstly, they discuss how the melting glaciers have already led to the flooding of coastal cities, and cut to an image of a flooded neighborhood. I think it is safe to say that no neighborhoods are permanently flooded yet, right? I'm sure that they took this picture from after a horrible storm, so that is blatant misinformation on their part. The graphs that they show aren't a very strong argument to me, and here's why. They show the increase in temperature, then the increase of carbon dioxide. The hockey stick-looking increase in the Carbon Dioxide graph has already been statistically disproven, yet we still show it in textbooks and youtube videos. Lastly, here is something I found very interesting the first time I heard it, and NatGeo was pretty ignorant to this. NatGeo claims that the rise in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere would end in world-wide drought and the lack of accessibility of clean water. But that just isn't reality. The Sahara desert, millions of years ago, was a rainforest. If you raise temperatures, you raise the possibility of evaporation and precipitation. If you raise that possibility of evaporation and precipitation, you receive a wetter climate. If anything, we would facilitate more of a jungle world than we would a desert, because it isn't like all of this water can go anywhere. It is stuck in our atmosphere and has to return as precipitation eventually. I feel that this video was either intentionally uninformed or new facts have been discovered since its filming.

@Garrett Wright If you haven't been convinced, then you simply have not sought out any convincing evidence yourself. Watch a basic 3 minute video right here on youtube called "Causes and Effects of Climate Change" by Nat Geo if you need convincing. If that's not good enough for you, go visit NASA's climate change evidence page: climate dot nasa dot gov slash evidence (youtube blocks comments with links in it sometimes). Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere haven't reached today's levels in hundreds of thousands of years. Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have increased by almost a third since the industrial revolution. We have satellite imagery tracking the progression of the melting polar ice caps which are melting at accelerating speeds, in accordance with the accerating rise in average surface temperatures... You've been distracted by industry apologists who are moving the goal posts from "are humans causing climate change" to "how MUCH are humans causing climate change" even though the body of evidence in support of anthropogenic climate change isn't nearly as ambiguous as they're making it out to be.

I was not claiming it qualified me for anything, I'm simply stating the weird adverse effect it had on my opinion. My problem is not that I can refute it, it is that I haven't been convinced. Again, I'm not saying it actually exists, I'm simply saying that there are reasonable criticisms of ANTHROPOGENIC climate change. Things like how the hockey graph has been disproven, along with false predictions made by the world's most prestigious climate scientists, has made me skeptical, that's all. I am not denying the greenhouse effect or the existence of greenhouse gas emissions, I'm really just curious as to how the small amount that we put out as compared to the atmosphere of our entire planet has really affected the climate as drastically as scientists have claimed. Again, I understand the whole claim that just because the number sounds small doesn't mean it is, but I have acquireed no information as to why it doesn't matter that it's so small.

" point of fact, the total worldwide estimate of roughly 55 MtCpa is by one researcher, rather than "scientists" in general.
